Award.AwardTitle: Solid Ionogel Electrolytes for Flexible Charge Storage Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches. The objective of this research is to demonstrate that high-performance, safe electrochemical double layer capacitors (supercapacitors) can be effectively fabricated on flexible substrates, transforming the rigid and bulky sealed devices of today into lightweight, solid-state energy storage platforms. The approach is to utilize the in situ immobilization of an ionic liquid in contact with high surface area electrodes to form a flexible ionogel electrolyte.

Intellectual Merit. Electrochemical double layer capacitors can meet the needs of many charge storage applications, bridging a gap in performance between batteries with high energy densities and ceramic capacitors that can provide high power through rapid discharge. Preliminary results indicate that ionogel capacitive behavior can be nearly equivalent to that of the neat ionic liquid, in spite of the electrolyte phase transformation from a liquid to a gel. This project seeks to further optimize ionogel performance by widening the range of gel formulations currently under study, to understand the capacitive behavior at the gel electrolyte/electrode interface, and to integrate thin ionogel electrolyte films into fully flexible device architectures.

Broader Impacts. This work will make an immediate and lasting impact on the field of flexible electronics and advance the development of ionogels as high performance solid electrolyte materials. Research activities will be integrated with science education, student training, and outreach to a broader audience through on-campus interaction with underrepresented minority high school students, graduate student leadership at a local energy conference, and development of new course materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the creation and characterization of ionic liquid-based solid electrolytes for their intended future application in capacitive electrical energy storage devices known as supercapacitors. Ionic liquids are salts that are molten at room temperature; they are also ionic conductors that are both nonvolatile and nonflammable. Their unique physical properties make ionic liquids a potentially safer class of electrolytes for energy storage devices. By synthesizing a polymer network inside the ionic liquid, a composite gel electrolyte material called an ionogel is formed. Ionogels exhibit solid-like properties (elastic deformation, no flow under their own weight) that are attractive for building flexible supercapacitors with reduced packaging requirements.

 

(Intellectual merit) The development of several new manifestations of polymer-supported ionogel electrolytes has been realized. Initially, a cross-linkable monomer that can react at two ends (poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate, PEGDA) was employed in a well-studied hydrophobic ionic liquid. In the presence of ultraviolet light, a photosensitive molecule generated free radicals that enabled the polymerization and cross-linking of PEGDA inside the ionic liquid. Varying the PEGDA molecular weight (size) within a certain range resulted in similar electrical and mechanical properties for all gels of a given composition above their minimum gelation point. Successful creation of PEGDA-based ionogels featuring different ionic liquids led to the demonstration of a record high ionogel ionic conductivity at room temperature (13.1 mS/cm) using a tetracyanoborate-based ionic liquid. Furthermore, an extremely rapid method of forming an ionogel (in only 10-20 seconds) using microwave irradiation was discovered during the course of this research. A novel processing method to obtain highly flexible and thermally stable silicone polymer-based ionogels has also been developed. It was observed that the energy storage performance of a given carbon paper electrode with a neat ionic liquid is not necessarily indicative of its behavior with the corresponding polymer-supported ionogel electrolyte. Additionally, varying the polymer side group chemical identity has been shown to alter the degree of ion pair dissociation inside the ionogel. This is important because some side groups were found to increase the degree of ion pair dissociation, leading to higher ionic conductivity (desirable), while other functional groups reduced the level of ionic dissociation compared to the neat ionic liquid (undesirable).

 

(Broader Impacts) Several educational and outreach activities were employed in order to widely disseminate the research findings of this project and to foster enthusiasm in U.S. students to study science and engineering. The PI presented results from this project during several invited seminars at various institutions of higher education, the PI and his graduate students discussed its findings at internationally renowned conferences, and the PI included aspects of the project in elective courses taught at Tufts University. The PI’s research group hosted a tour of his laboratory at Tufts for approximately 40 elementary school students in 2012. During the summers of 2013 and 2014, the PI supervised two local high school students as research assistants in his laboratory. In addition, funding for this project provided valuable opportunities for the professional and educational development of 6 graduate and 6 undergraduate students at Tufts University; 5 of the 12 participants were female. This project contributed to the production of several significant products, including: 8 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 PhD theses, and 1 MS thesis.

 


Last Modified: 04/04/2016
Modified by: Matthew Panzer
